State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering Beijing University of Chemical Technology Beijing 100029 PR China Graphical abstract The selective hydrogenation of acetylene using Pd-based catalysts is often limited by high precious metal usage and competitive adsorption between hydrogen and acetylene on active sites, which reduces catalytic efficiency. To address this, we developed a PdAg catalyst supported on La-doped Al2O3, introducing O-(La) sites that enhance hydrogen storage and transfer. In-situ Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR), temperature-programmed desorption (TPD), and mass spectrometry analyses revealed that the O-(La) sites enable efficient storage of dissociated hydrogen, which selectively reacts with acetylene, reducing competition on Pd sites. Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations confirmed that the O-(La) sites reduce the energy barrier for hydrogen migration and enhance acetylene hydrogenation. This innovative approach reduces the Pd content by up to 30% while achieving superior catalytic performance, offering a cost-effective and scalable solution for industrial hydrogenation processes. Keywords O-(La) site Hydrogen transfer Al2O3 Acetylene hydrogenation Equivalent decrement Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethylene is a fundamental feedstock in the petrochemical industry, serving as the precursor for approximately 75 % of petrochemical products [1,2]. The predominant industrial method for ethylene production is naphtha cracking, which inevitably generates trace amounts of acetylene impurities. These impurities can poison catalysts, reduce efficiency, and compromise the quality of downstream products. To purify ethylene, selective catalytic hydrogenation is widely employed [3]. Among various hydrogenation catalysts, palladium (Pd)-based catalysts are preferred due to their exceptional hydrogenation activity and selectivity for acetylene [4]. However, the broad application of Pd catalysts is often restricted by the high cost and limited availability of precious metals. Consequently, there is a significant interest in reducing the precious metal content of Pd-based catalysts without sacrificing their catalytic performance. A promising strategy to lower Pd usage involves enhancing the hydrogenation efficiency of catalysts, particularly by improving hydrogen transfer mechanisms [5]. Hydrogen spillover, a well-studied phenomenon, has been explored as a potential method to enhance hydrogen usage efficiency in catalytic systems [6]. In this process, hydrogen is initially activated and dissociate into hydrogen atoms (H*) and these hydrogen atoms subsequently migrate onto the surface or into the bulk of adjacent support materials [7–9]. This facilitates the hydrogenation of acetylene and other substrates, optimizing hydrogen utilization and boosting reaction efficiency. However, the effectiveness of hydrogen transfer is highly dependent on the nature of the support material. Reducible supports, such as CeO2 [10] and TiO2 [11], enhance hydrogen storage and transfer through oxygen vacancies, while non-reducible supports like SiO2 [12] and Al2O3 [13] are less efficient in this regard. Alumina, known for its remarkable stability, versatility, and cost-effectiveness, is extensively used as a catalyst support in industrial applications [14]. However, its non-reducible nature limits the mobility of surface-active hydrogen species, thereby constraining the hydrogenation performance of metal-supported catalysts. Given that active metals, especially precious ones, are typically present in minimal amounts due to economic and practical considerations, competitive adsorption of reactants and intermediates on limited metal surface sites is unavoidable. Various strategies have been employed to enhance the intrinsic activity of metal sites—such as tuning the d-band center [15], exposing high-index facets [16], forming alloy structures [17], and increasing metal dispersion into clusters or single atoms [18]. Despite these advancements, the issue of competitive adsorption remains unresolved, and the potential of alumina as a support for hydrogenation is not fully exploited. Therefore, it is crucial to develop strategies that enhance the hydrogen transfer and storage capabilities of non-reducible oxide supports like alumina. Recent studies have demonstrated that non-reducible supports can be modified to improve hydrogen storage and transfer capabilities [19,20]. For instance, incorporating rare earth elements such as La into an Al2O3 support can generate oxygen-rich (O-La) sites, which enhance hydrogen transfer within the catalyst system [21]. The hydrogen transfer process described here includes H2 spillover, while explicitly indicating that hydrogen undergoes adsorption and desorption at specific O-La sites, thereby participating in the catalytic process. In our previous research [21], a Pd/La-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited significant improvements in hydrogenation efficiency, highlighting the potential of modified supports to enhance catalytic performance. This study investigates the impact of support modification on hydrogen transfer properties and the efficient utilization of Pd. Specifically, the introduction of La into an Al2O3 support, along with the formation of O-(La) sites, was found to facilitate efficient hydrogen storage and transfer. This modification enables a reduction in Pd loading while maintaining robust catalytic activity, thus offering a viable approach to optimize catalyst performance in hydrogenation reactions. 2 Experiment section 2.1 Sample preparation Synthesis of Al2O3 based support. Accurately weigh 100.00 g of alumina sol (11.5 wt%), 2.35 g of crosslinking agent (polyacrylamide, 30 wt% solid content), and 32.04 g of hexamethylenetetramine solution (40 wt%). Mix thoroughly, then cool the mixture. Using a homemade needle, form spheres by droplet formation. After obtaining the semi-cured alumina sol spheres through oil-drop forming, the samples were placed in a reactor. The reactor was initially purged with N2 at room temperature, and the pressure was adjusted to 0.6 MPa. The temperature was then increased at a rate of 5 °C/min to 145 °C. During this heating process, the reaction between hexamethylenetetramine and formaldehyde releases gases, leading to a gradual pressure increase inside the reactor. When the pressure exceeded 0.65 MPa, depressurization was performed to bring the pressure back to the desired level. This cyclic depressurization process ensures controlled pressure conditions throughout the reaction. Once the target temperature of 145 °C was reached, the system was maintained at this temperature for 2 h to ensure complete reaction. Afterward, the reactor was cooled while maintaining a 0.6 MPa pressure overnight before retrieving the alumina spheres. After aging, allow the reactor to cool to room temperature, retrieve the spheres, and rinse thoroughly with deionized water until free from oil and chloride ions. Dry the spheres in an oven at 110 °C for 12 h. Then, calcine 20 g of the dried spheres at 960 °C for 4 h to obtain θ-Al2O3 with a diameter of 2.4–2.5 mm. Another batch of 20 g is calcined at 1250 °C for 4 h to yield α-Al2O3 with a diameter of 2 mm. For La-Al2O3 supports, dissolve 100 g of alumina sol (11.5 wt%) and 2.678 g of lanthanum nitrate hexahydrate, following the same procedure as θ-Al2O3. Another 20 g batch is calcined at 1400 °C for 8 h, yielding La-α-Al2O3 with 5 wt% lanthanum and a diameter of 1.8 mm. Synthesis of 3.5-Pd/Al2O3. The 3.5-Pd/Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by two steps impregnation-gas phase reduction method. The theoretical Pd loading is 0.035 wt%. 330 mL of 50 mmol/L Na2PdCl4 solution, 6 mg urea and 10 mL deionized water were mixed with spheres and shaken every 10 min for 2 h. Subsequently, the spheres were removed the supernatant and aged in the oven and calcined at 450 ℃ for 3 h. 3.5-Pd/Al2O3 catalyst was obtained by reducing at 700 °C for 1h in 10 % H2/N2 atmosphere. Due to the low metal loading in 3.5-Pd/Al2O3, we prepared Pd/Al2O3 with 1 wt% Pd loading and named it as Pd/Al2O3 for characterization. Synthesis of Ag/Al2O3. According to the measured water absorption rate of the spherical support, 1 wt% Ag precursor (10 mmol/L AgNO3 solution) and 6.67 mL deionized water were added to the separatory funnel. The solution was placed on top of a filter flask containing 5.00 g Al2O3 support. The vacuum pump was used to create negative pressure, and then the solution was added slowly until the support was just soaked. The spheres were aged in the oven and calcined at 450 ℃ for 3 h to obtain Ag/Al2O3. Synthesis of series PdAg alloy-based catalyst. The 3.5-PdAg/Al2O3 catalyst was also prepared by two steps impregnation-gas phase reduction method. The theoretical Pd loading is 0.035 wt%, and the Pd/Ag molar ratio is 2:1. According to the measured water absorption rate of the spherical support, 830 mL of 10 mmol/L AgNO3 solution and 6.67 mL deionized water were added to the separatory funnel. The solution was placed on top of a filter flask containing 5.00 g Al2O3 support. The vacuum pump was used to create negative pressure, and then the solution was added slowly until the support was just soaked. The spheres were aged in the oven and calcined at 450 ℃ for 3 h. Then 330 mL of 50 mmol/L Na2PdCl4 solution, 6 mg urea and 10 mL deionized water were mixed with spheres and shaken every 10 min for 2 h. Subsequently, the spheres were removed the supernatant and aged in the oven and calcined at 450 ℃ for 3 h to obtain 3.5-PdAg/Al2O3. The theoretical of Pd loading is 0.05 wt% for 5-PdAg/Al2O3. The theoretical of Pd loading is 1 wt% for PdAg/Al2O3. The La-Al2O3 is used to prepare 3.5-PdAg/La-Al2O3 and PdAg/La-Al2O3. Synthesis of series (α)Al2O3 based catalysts. The preparation method of PdAg/(α)Al2O3 and PdAg/La-(α)Al2O3 is same with the 3.5-PdAg/Al2O3 despite for the support is (α)Al2O3 and La-(α)Al2O3. The desired amount of KNO3 is added in the AgNO3 solution to obtain PdAg/La-(α)Al2O3-K0.5, PdAg/La-(α)Al2O3-K1, and PdAg/La-(α)Al2O3-K3. 2.2 Characterizations X-ray diffractometer (XRD) (Rigaku Smart Lab SE) was used to characterize the crystal structure of samples with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm, 40 kV, 40 mA) in the range of 3 ∼ 80°. The specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size of the supports were analyzed using a Gemini VII BET analyzer. First, the mass of the empty sample tube was recorded, and approximately 100 mg of spherical particles were added to the tube. The sample was degassed under high-purity N2 at 100 °C for 2 h. Afterward, the mass of the sample tube with the sample was measured, and the actual sample mass was determined by subtracting the empty tube mass. The sample tube was then mounted on the instrument for analysis. The BET method was used to determine the specific surface area, while the BJH method was applied to analyze the pore structure information of the sample. 27Al magic-angle spinning nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (27Al MAS NMR) was carried out on the solid-state nuclear magnetic spectrometer (Bruker 400WB AVANCE Ⅲ) to determine the coordination structure of Al3+. An inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy analysis (Perklin-Elmer 2100 DV) was a reliable way to determine the content of Pd, Ag and La (Table S4). JEOLJEM-2100F high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) equipped with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) was used to characterize the morphology of the supports and catalysts. The samples were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using an Axis Supra instrument equipped with an Al Kα excitation source, with spectral calibration based on the standard C 1s binding energy of 284.6 eV. Hydrogen Temperature Programmed Reduction (H2-TPR) analysis of the reduced sample was conducted using a MicroActive for AutoChem II 2920 system. A U-shaped quartz tube was loaded with 20 mg of sample and 40 mg of iron oxide, positioned so that H2 gas flowed through the sample first and then through the iron oxide. The sample was initially heated to 300 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min under 30 mL/min of Ar flow and held for 30 min, then cooled to 50 °C. A 10 % H2/Ar mixture was introduced for 30 min to equilibrate, and after the baseline stabilized, the temperature was ramped to 800 °C at 10 °C/min, with TCD signals recorded. The in situ FTIR spectra of D2 and D2-CO adsorption were recorded using a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer. A 30 mg catalyst sample was pretreated at 200 °C under a 10 % H2/N2 atmosphere for 30 min, followed by an Ar purge down to room temperature to collect the background spectrum. In the in situ D2 experiment, D2 was introduced at a flow rate of 5 mL/min, and infrared spectra were recorded every minute until saturation was reached. For the D2-CO co-adsorption experiment, CO was first introduced until saturation, then physically adsorbed CO was removed by an Ar purge, after which the gas was switched to D2 (5 mL/min) and spectra were recorded every minute until stabilization. To further investigate hydrogen storage performance, a temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) was conducted. The gas was switched to a 1 % C2H2/C2H4 mixture and heated up to 70 °C, with m/z values of 31, 33, and 34 (corresponding to C2H5D1 or C2H4D2, C2H1D4 or C2H3D3, and C2H2D4) monitored online using Hiden EXQ mass spectrometer. 2.3 Acetylene hydrogenation The evaluation was conducted in a fixed-bed microreactor using a quartz tube with a length of 30 cm and an inner diameter of 1 cm. The system was equipped with a 0.53 mm × 50 m alumina capillary column and an online gas chromatograph with a flame ionization detector (FID) for product analysis. The total gas flow rate was maintained at 160 mL/min with a H2/C2H2 molar ratio of 2. The inlet gas mixture consisted of 0.63 % H2, 30.9 % ethylene, and 0.31 % acetylene, giving a space velocity of 2065 h−1 (gas hourly space velocity, GHSV). The procedure was as follows: precisely 2 g of catalyst was weighed and placed at the center of the quartz tube, which was then installed in the microreactor. Prior to testing, the catalyst was reduced at 700 °C in a 10 % H2/N2 mixture flowing at 40 mL/min for 1 h, followed by purging with nitrogen at 500 °C to cool the system to room temperature. Online gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-2014C) was used to analyze the product composition. Initial gas composition was recorded in an empty tube at room temperature, and the reaction temperature was then gradually increased. Measurements were taken after a 30-minute stabilization period at each temperature, continuing until complete acetylene conversion was achieved. The reported values were the average of the last three measurements out of five. The formulas for calculating conversion and selectivity are as follows: Acetyleneconversion = Acetylene ( i n ) - Acetylene ( o u t ) Acetylene ( i n ) Ethyleneselectivity = Ethylene ( o u t ) - Ethylene ( i n ) Acetylene ( i n ) - Acetylene ( o u t ) Ethaneselectivity = Ethane ( o u t ) - Ethane ( i n ) Acetylene ( i n ) - Acetylene ( o u t ) Oligomersselectivity = 1 - E t h y l e n e s e l e c t i v i t y - E t h a n e s e l e c t i v i t y The turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated based on the surface Pd atoms, TOF ( s - 1 ) = Acetylene ( m o l / s ) Pd ( m o l , s u r f a c e ) A surface atom fraction of approximately 25 % was estimated for Pd nanoparticles with an average diameter of 4 ∼ 5 nm (Fig. S3), according to a model reported by Gates [22]. 2.4 DFT calculation A θ-Al2O3 model was selected and subjected to geometric optimization, yielding stable unit cell parameters: a = b = 4.84 Å, c = 13.26 Å, α = β = 90°, γ = 120°. Based on the literature, the (010) surface was chosen and expanded to a (2 × 1) supercell, comprising 32 Al atoms and 48O atoms, with dimensions a = 13.26 Å and b = 9.68 Å. A 15 Å vacuum layer was added to eliminate periodic interaction effects. The optimized θ-Al2O3 (010) surface model was used for subsequent studies. The La-Al2O3 model was constructed by substituting selected Al atoms with La atoms in the optimized θ-Al2O3 and similarly optimized. Calculations were performed using the GGA-PBE functional within the CASTEP module of Materials Studio. The optimization criteria were set to an energy convergence threshold of <2.0 × 10−5 eV/atom, a maximum force of <0.05 eV/Å, and a maximum displacement of <0.002 Å. A cutoff energy of 400 eV and OTFG ultrasoft pseudopotentials were employed, with an SCF tolerance of 2.0 × 10−5. The unit cell optimization was set to full, while surface optimization was set to None. Transition state searches and frequency optimizations were conducted using the DMol3 module, utilizing the LST/QST method to ensure that the final structure exhibited only one imaginary frequency. The adsorption energy (Eads) was calculated using the formula: Eads = Esurface/absorbate − Esurface – Eabsorbate where Esurface/adsorbate represents the energy of the system after adsorption, Esurface is the energy of the surface, and Eadsorbate is the energy of the adsorbate. The actual catalyst consists of Pd nanoparticles with an average diameter of approximately 4 nm, direct modeling of such large systems using DFT is currently computationally prohibitive due to the extensive number of atoms involved. To address this, a simplified periodic slab model was adopted to represent the surface of the Pd-based alloy, which is generally regarded as the catalytically active region. While this approach does not fully capture the three-dimensional structure of nanoparticles, it preserves key local atomic and electronic characteristics of the alloy surface that govern adsorption and reaction processes. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Geometric properties of supports The XRD patterns of the supports and catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 a. Both Al2O3 and La-Al2O3 supports display diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 31.2°, 32.7°, 36.6°, 44.9°, 47.4°, and 67.2°, consistent with the θ-Al2O3 phase as identified by the JCPDS 35-0121 PDF card, with calcination at 960 °C. The reduced intensity of La-Al2O3 peaks indicates that La addition lowers the crystallinity of the support without altering the Al2O3 crystal structure. Additionally, weak peaks at 23.5°, 33.3°, 41.2°, 47.9°, 54.0°, 59.7°, and 70.2° correspond to LaAlO3 (JCPDS 31-0022), suggesting a solid-state reaction between Al2O3 and La3+ and confirming successful La incorporation into the Al2O3 lattice. Nitrogen adsorption isotherms (Fig. S1) show type IV adsorption curves and H1-type hysteresis loops for both La-Al2O3 and Al2O3. A slight reduction in pore volume and pore size for La-Al2O3, as indicated in Table S1, suggests that the incorporation of La subtly perturbs the support structure. The coordination structure of Al3+, analyzed using 27Al MAS NMR (Fig. 1 b), exhibits two significant peaks at 5–7 ppm and 58–61 ppm in both La-Al2O3 and Al2O3 samples, representing octahedral (Al3+ octa) and tetrahedral (Al3+ tetra) aluminum coordination [23]. The tetra-to-octahedral Al3+ ratio (0.52, Table S2) for La-Al2O3 is lower than that of Al2O3 (0.74), suggesting that La replaces Al3+ in the tetrahedral sites within the alumina lattice, verifying the incorporation of La. 3.2 Selective acetylene hydrogenation To further investigate the impact of La doping at the Al tetrahedral sites on hydrogenation reaction processes, we prepared a series of Pd-based catalysts (3.5-Pd/Al2O3, 3.5-PdAg/Al2O3, 5-PdAg/Al2O3, and 3.5-PdAg/La-Al2O3) for use in the semi-hydrogenation of acetylene. As shown in Fig. 2 a, b, the complete conversion temperature for 3.5-Pd/Al2O3 is 60 °C, with an ethylene yield of 57 %. When the common promoter Ag, known to improve ethylene yield [24,25], was added, there was a slight increase in ethylene selectivity (Figs. 2 b and S2a), but the catalytic activity of the resulting 3.5-PdAg/Al2O3 catalyst significantly decreased. To compensate for this activity loss, the Pd loading was increased by 42 %, and the resulting 5-PdAg/Al2O3 catalyst achieved complete acetylene conversion at a temperature similar to that of 3.5-Pd/Al2O3. Interestingly, the 3.5-PdAg/La-Al2O3 catalyst was able to offset the negative impact of Ag on catalytic activity while maintaining a lower Pd loading level, achieving complete acetylene conversion at a reduced temperature of 54 °C. This suggests that La-Al2O3 significantly enhances the hydrogenation performance of Pd catalysts. To gain deeper insight into the catalytic behavior, we conducted a detailed performance analysis and calculated the turnover frequency (TOF, based on surface Pd atoms) for each catalyst. The TOF values further highlight the promotional effect of La: 3.5-Pd/Al2O3 exhibited a TOF of 0.019 s−1, while 3.5-PdAg/Al2O3 showed a slightly lower value of 0.016 s−1 due to suppressed activity. Upon increasing the Pd content, 5-PdAg/Al2O3 reached a higher TOF of 0.024 s−1. Notably, 3.5-PdAg/La-Al2O3 delivered the highest TOF of 0.049 s−1, more than double that of the base 3.5-Pd catalyst. These results confirm that La incorporation into the Al2O3 support not only compensates for the activity loss caused by Ag addition but also significantly enhances the intrinsic activity of the Pd sites. As depicted in Fig. 2 b, 3.5-PdAg/La-Al2O3 achieves a 70 % ethylene yield at 53 °C, outperforming both 3.5-PdAg/Al2O3 and 5-PdAg/Al2O3, which reached 61 % at 57 °C and 80 °C, respectively. Simultaneously, the side produce like ethane and oligomeric selectivity remains at relative low level for 3.5-PdAg/La-Al2O3 (Fig. S2b, c). Stability evaluations of the 3.5-PdAg/La-Al2O3 catalyst reveal that La is effectively stabilized at Al tetrahedral sites. Thus, the formation of new active sites due to La incorporation in La-Al2O3 not only improves the activity of the acetylene hydrogenation catalyst but also presents a promising approach for reducing the usage of precious metals in catalytic processes. 3.3 Role of incorporated La species For 3.5-PdAg/Al2O3 and 3.5-PdAg/La-Al2O3, the differed catalytic performance might origin from the incorporate La species in Al2O3 matrix. The Pd loading was increased to 1 wt% for TEM and XPS characterization and named as PdAg/Al2O3 and PdAg/La-Al2O3. The PdAg particle distribution of the catalysts was studied using HRTEM. The average particle size was estimated by count at least 200 particles. In PdAg/La-Al2O3, the La species was found to be atomically dispersed on the support without local agglomeration (Fig. S4). In Fig. 3 a, d, the results show that PdAg/La-Al2O3 and PdAg/Al2O3 have comparable average particle of 4.4 and 4.5 nm, respectively. The alloy state of PdAg particle was confirmed by analyzing the interplanar spacing of the catalysts. The interplanar spacing (Fig. 3 b, e) was calculated to be 0.225 nm and 0.220 nm for 3.5-PdAg/La-Al2O3 and 3.5-PdAg/Al2O3 catalysts, corresponding to the (111) crystal face of PdAg alloy [26,27]. In addition, the EDS mapping results (Fig. 3 c, f) show that the Pd and Ag species emerge simultaneously with the function of distance. This also confirm that the Pd and Ag species exists in the metal alloy state. Fig. S5 show that the introduction of the second metal Ag reduced the binding energy of Pd0 in Pd/Al2O3 from 336.1 eV to 335.5 eV (PdAg/Al2O3 and PdAg/La-Al2O3) [28,29]. The binding energy of Ag in Ag/Al2O3 catalyst was increased from 367.3 eV to 367.8 eV (PdAg/Al2O3) and 367.6 eV (PdAg/La-Al2O3). The results show that the existence of charge transfer between Pd and Ag species when Pd and Ag are in alloy state [30,31]. And Pd species is favorable to accept electron from Ag species, which is beneficial to improve the ethylene selectivity of acetylene hydrogenation. To evaluate the hydrogen storage capabilities of the catalysts, 40 mg of iron oxide samples were added, while 20 mg 3.5-PdAg/La-Al2O3 and 3.5-PdAg/Al2O3 catalysts were added for each test, separately. In Fig. 4 a, it was observed that at 300–400 ℃, Fe2O3 reacted with hydrogen gas to produce Fe3O4 and at 400–800 ℃, further hydrogenation of Fe3O4 yielded Fe [32,33]. Specifically, the 3.5-PdAg/La-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited an inverted peak at 296 ℃, indicating partial hydrogen desorption. This phenomenon suggested that hydrogen stored at the O-(La) site was released at high temperatures, manifesting in the signal observed. The subsequent reduction temperature of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4 showed minor difference among catalysts. The further reduction of Fe3O4 to Fe occurs at 675 °C in pure Fe2O3, and a similar temperature is observed for the 3.5-PdAg/Al2O3 catalyst, indicating that the presence of the PdAg alloy does not significantly affect the hydrogen storage capacity. Notably, the highest reduction temperature of Fe3O4 species is observed in the 3.5-PdAg/La-Al2O3 catalyst, suggesting that the O-(La) sites facilitate the hydrogen spillover and storage processes. The enhanced hydrogen storage ability of the catalyst delays the re-release of H2 on the surface, leading to a pronounced shift of the Fe3O4 reduction peak toward higher temperatures. The catalysts were further characterized using H2-TPD, with results shown in Fig. 4 b. All catalysts exhibited a single desorption peak. The hydrogen desorption peak for the 3.5-Pd/Al2O3 catalyst appeared at 90 ℃. Upon introduction of the second metal Ag, the desorption peak shifted to a higher temperature of 155 ℃, indicating reduced adsorption capacity of Pd species for active hydrogen due to interactions with Ag. However, incorporation of La species caused the desorption peak to shift in the opposite direction to a lower temperature (101 ℃). Moreover, the peak area of the 3.5-PdAg/La-Al2O3 catalyst was notably larger than that of the 3.5-Pd/Al2O3 catalyst, indicating higher hydrogen species storage capacity. Consequently, more hydrogen species were released from the surface of the 3.5-PdAg/La-Al2O3 catalyst, enhancing the fluidity of active hydrogen species and thereby improving the activity of the acetylene hydrogenation reaction. In-situ FTIR experiments were conducted to further investigate the role of the O-(La) sites in reactive environments. First, PdAg/La-Al2O3 and PdAg/Al2O3 catalysts underwent reduction treatment, followed by D2 introduction into the cell until adsorption saturation was achieved. Notably, no D2 adsorption peaks were detected on the PdAg/Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 5 a). The PdAg/La-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited an O-D bond absorption peak in the 2000–2800 cm−1 range (Fig. 5 b) [34], indicating the presence of a hydrogen storage-capable structure in La-Al2O3. As shown in Fig. S6, the Ag/La-Al2O3 sample exhibited O-D bond signals in the range of 2400–2600 cm−1. In contrast, La-Al2O3 showed negligible O-D bond signals, confirming the absence of H2 activation and dissociation functionality. These results highlight that active metal components, such as Pd or Ag, are essential for enabling the hydrogen transfer functionality of O-(La) sites. Without these components, as seen in La-Al2O3 alone, the O-La sites remain inert. For the in-situ FTIR CO-D2 co-adsorption experiment, CO was initially adsorbed on the catalyst, with physically adsorbed CO subsequently removed using Ar gas. The chemisorption peaks of CO appeared at 1900–2100 cm−1, corresponding to linear and bridge adsorption modes on Pd sites [35]. Upon the introduction of D2, infrared spectra were collected as shown in Fig. 5 c. Increased with prolonged D2 exposure, a D2 adsorption peak was observed at 2100–2800 cm−1 with no significant impact on the CO chemisorption strength, suggesting the existence of two distinct adsorption sites for CO and D2. This implies that the O-(La) site serves as a non-competitive adsorption site for both H2 and Pd metal related molecular adsorption (CO and acetylene). To assess the reactivity of the H species stored on O-(La) sites, in-situ acetylene hydrogenation experiments were conducted using D2. Once the O-D adsorption peak reached saturation on O-(La) sites (as indicated by stable peak intensity), the D2 flow was halted, and a 1 % acetylene/ethylene gas mixture was introduced over the PdAg/La-Al2O3 catalyst at 70 °C (Fig. 5 d). The O-D adsorption peak decreased concurrently with the accumulation of CC stretching bands (1600–1700 cm−1) and the enhancement of asymmetric CH absorption bands (3000–3200 cm−1). Additionally, a mass spectrometer connected to the infrared reaction device collected gas samples post-reaction (Fig. 5 e). Analysis of the mass spectra at different reaction times revealed fragment ions such as m/z = 31, 33, and 34, corresponding to isotopes like C2H5D1 or C2H4D2, C2H1D4 or C2H3D3, and C2H2D4, respectively. These findings confirm the involvement of D2 in acetylene hydrogenation. Overall, the results demonstrate that the O-(La) sites effectively store H species, which can then react with acetylene. Moreover, the presence of O-(La) sites significantly alleviates competitive adsorption between H2 and acetylene on Pd sites, thereby enhancing catalyst activity. 3.4 DFT calculations The function of O-(La) in acetylene hydrogenation was analyzed using density functional theory (DFT). To investigate the effects of the La-Al2O3 support on the migration of active hydrogen and determine whether the O-(La) site has a more advantageous hydrogen storage capacity, the energy barriers for active hydrogen migration from the vicinity of PdAg alloy clusters to the O-(La) and O-(Al) sites on the surface were calculated (Fig. 6 ). The results showed that the energy barriers for these migrations were 1.73 eV and 2.11 eV, respectively. This indicates that active hydrogen more easily migrates to the La-Al2O3 surface, demonstrating a more favorable hydrogen storage at the O-(La) site. To exclude potential transport limitations, both external and internal diffusion effects were thoroughly evaluated. The Weisz–Prater number was well below the threshold of 0.3, and conversion rates decreased linearly with increasing flow rate (Table S3, Fig. S7), confirming that the observed kinetics are free from diffusion limitations. A linear increase in acetylene conversion was observed with increasing catalyst loading, further supporting that the catalyst and reaction conditions used in this study operate within the kinetic regime (Fig. S8). Additionally, hydrogen reaction order analysis (Fig. S9) shows that 3.5-PdAg/La-Al2O3 decreases the value from 1.84 (for 3.5-PdAg/Al2O3) to 1.47, implying that the surface of 3.5-PdAg/La-Al2O3 is more favorable for H2 adsorption in the vicinity of O-(La) sites. Similarly, the incorporation of O-La sites can also effectively lower the reaction order of Pd/Al2O3 (Fig. S10), further highlighting the role of O-La sites in promoting the surface diffusion of hydrogen. To better understand the role of O–La sites in the catalytic hydrogenation of acetylene, we conducted DFT calculations on PdAg/Al2O3 and PdAg/La-Al2O3. Fig. 7 systematically compares the reaction energy profiles and mechanistic pathways of PdAg/Al2O3 and PdAg/La-Al2O3 during the hydrogenation of ethylene. As shown in Fig. 7 a, the PdAg/La-Al2O3 system (light blue curve) exhibits a substantially lower energy barrier for H2 activation (0.15 eV) compared to PdAg/Al2O3 (black curve, 1.13 eV), indicating that the introduction of La significantly facilitates the activation and spillover of hydrogen. Since H2 activation represents the initial and critical step of the hydrogenation process, this improvement directly enhances the overall reaction kinetics. Throughout the formation of hydrogenated intermediates, PdAg/La-Al2O3 consistently shows similar transition-state energy barriers relative to PdAg/Al2O3, particularly in the transformation from intermediate [2] to [4]. This observation indicates that the O–La sites mainly promote the catalytic reaction by enhancing the adsorption and diffusion of H2 on the catalyst surface, rather than by significantly lowering the energy barriers for the formation of hydrogenated intermediates. The corresponding structural evolution during the reaction is illustrated in Fig. 7 b and c. In the case of PdAg/La-Al2O3 (Fig. 7 b), H2 molecules readily dissociate on O–La sites, and the generated atomic hydrogen rapidly migrates to nearby metallic centers, thereby promoting ethylene hydrogenation. In contrast, for PdAg/Al2O3 (Fig. 7 c), H2 spillover via O–Al sites is assumed, the associated energy barriers are significantly higher. Notably, the rate-determining step (RDS) barrier reaches 1.25 eV in the absence of La, compared to 0.91 eV for the La-modified system. This suggests that O–Al sites are less effective in mediating hydrogen spillover, ultimately limiting the hydrogenation efficiency. Moreover, the presence of La not only lowers the energy barrier for H2 activation but also streamlines the hydrogen migration pathway, stabilizing reaction intermediates and reducing kinetic bottlenecks. Such an enhanced hydrogen supply mechanism enables ethylene hydrogenation to proceed with lower energetic demands, culminating in improved catalytic activity and performance. In summary, the incorporation of La into the Al2O3 support modifies the local structural and electronic environment, thereby significantly promoting H2 activation and spillover, decreasing the energy barriers of key reaction steps, and enhancing the overall catalytic behavior for ethylene hydrogenation. 3.5 Engineering application of O-(La) site in selective hydrogenation of acetylene For industrial acetylene hydrogenation catalysts, Al2O3 typically requires high-temperature calcination, and the introduction of alkali metals is employed to reduce the number of strong acid sites [36,37]. To further explore the potential industrial applications of O-(La) sites, we synthesized a series of Pd-based catalysts supported on α-Al2O3, modified with potassium (K). As shown in Fig. S11 and Table S5, the introduction of La effectively eliminates strong acid sites on the catalyst. Furthermore, the addition of K reduced the strong acid site density from 26.6 μmol/g by approximately 96 %. After modification with La doping and K treatment, the acidic sites on the catalyst surface were almost completely eliminated. Subsequently, the acetylene hydrogenation performance of the prepared catalysts was evaluated, as detailed in Table 1 . Among the catalysts tested, the PdAg/La-(α) Al2O3-K1, with a Pd loading of 0.035 wt%, achieved an ethylene yield of 75.2 % at 83.8 °C, which is competitive with the highest values in mild conditions reported in the literature. Notably, during the evaluation, the H2/C2H2 ratio of our catalysts was significantly lower than that of other reported systems, indicating a lower hydrogen concentration required for the reaction. By modifying the non-reducible Al2O3 support, we successfully constructed O-(La) sites capable of storing and transferring active hydrogen on the support surface. This modification increased the surface concentration of active hydrogen, thereby enhancing the catalyst activity. Therefore, the modification of Al2O3 supports with O-(La) sites demonstrates significant advantages in acetylene hydrogenation, highlighting its potential for industrial applications. 4 Conclusion This study successfully demonstrates the enhancement of selective acetylene hydrogenation by incorporating La into the Al2O3 support, resulting in the formation of O-(La) sites that significantly improve hydrogen storage and transfer capabilities. The 3.5-PdAg/La-Al2O3 catalyst exhibited superior performance compared to traditional Pd-based catalysts, achieving higher ethylene yields at lower temperatures while reducing the overall precious metal content by up to 30 %. The in-situ FTIR and mass spectrometry analyses confirmed that the O-(La) sites efficiently store dissociated hydrogen for selective reaction with acetylene. Moreover, DFT calculations revealed that the presence of O-(La) sites lowers the energy barrier for hydrogen transfer and enhances the adsorption efficiency of acetylene, thereby promoting the overall hydrogenation process. The findings suggest that the strategic introduction of rare earth elements like La into catalyst supports can serve as a viable approach to optimize the efficiency of hydrogenation reactions, offering a promising pathway for reducing the dependency on precious metals in industrial applications. These insights not only advance the understanding of hydrogen transfer mechanisms but also provide a foundation for designing cost-effective catalysts with improved performance for selective hydrogenation processes. coredata.dc:description: The selective hydrogenation of acetylene using Pd-based catalysts is often limited by high precious metal usage and competitive adsorption between hydrogen and acetylene on active sites, which reduces catalytic efficiency. To address this, we developed a PdAg catalyst supported on La-doped Al2O3, introducing O-(La) sites that enhance hydrogen storage and transfer. In-situ Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR), temperature-programmed desorption (TPD), and mass spectrometry analyses revealed that the O-(La) sites enable efficient storage of dissociated hydrogen, which selectively reacts with acetylene, reducing competition on Pd sites. Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations confirmed that the O-(La) sites reduce the energy barrier for hydrogen migration and enhance acetylene hydrogenation. This innovative approach reduces the Pd content by up to 30% while achieving superior catalytic performance, offering a cost-effective and scalable solution for industrial hydrogenation processes.

coredata.dc:title: O-(La)-promoted hydrogen transfer enables low-loading Pd catalysts for selective acetylene hydrogenation
